sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using Cramer's rule
message_1:
Given the following system of equations, solve for the values of x, y and z using Cramer's rule:
 
3x - 2y + 4z = 6,
4x + 3y + z = 7,
2x + 5y - 3z = 2.
message_2:
To solve the system of equations using Cramer's rule, we first need to find the determinant of the coefficient matrix (D), and then the determinants of the matrices obtained by replacing the columns with the constants (Dx, Dy, Dz).

The coefficient matrix is:
| 3 -2  4 |
| 4  3  1 |
| 2  5 -3 |

To find the determinant D, we use the rule for 3x3 matrices:
D = 3(3(-3) - 1(5)) - (-2)(4(-3) - 1(2)) + 4(4(5) - 3(2))
D = 3(-9 - 5) - (-2)(-12 - 2) + 4(20 - 6)
D = 3(-14) - (-2)(-14) + 4(14)
D = -42 + 28 + 56
D = 42

Now, we'll find the determinant Dx by replacing the first column with the constants (6, 7, 2):
| 6 -2  4 |
| 7  3  1 |
| 2  5 -3 |

Dx = 6(3(-3) - 1(5)) - (-2)(7(-3) - 1(2)) + 4(7(5) - 3(2))
Dx = 6(-9 - 5) - (-2)(-21 - 2) + 4(35 - 6)
Dx = 6(-14) - (-2)(-23) + 4(29)
Dx = -84 + 46 + 116
Dx = 78

Now, we'll find the determinant Dy by replacing the second column with the constants (6, 7, 2):
| 3  6  4 |
| 4  7  1 |
| 2  2 -3 |

Dy = 3(7(-3) - 1(2)) - 6(4(-3) - 1(2)) + 4(4(2) - 7(2))
Dy = 3(-21 - 2) - 6(-12 - 2) + 4(8 - 14)
Dy = 3(-23) - 6(-14) + 4(-6)
Dy = -69 + 84 - 24
Dy = -9

Now, we'll find the determinant Dz by replacing the third column with the constants (6, 7, 2):
| 3 -2  6 |
| 4  3  7 |
| 2  5  2 |

Dz = 3(3(2) - 7(5)) - (-2)(4(2) - 7(2)) + 6(4(5) - 3(2))
Dz = 3(6 - 35) - (-2)(8 - 14) + 6(20 - 6)
Dz = 3(-29) - (-2)(-6) + 6(14)
Dz = -87 + 12 + 84
Dz = 9

Now, we can find the values of x, y, and z using the determinants:

x = Dx / D = 78 / 42 = 13/7
y = Dy / D = -9 / 42 = -3/14
z = Dz / D = 9 / 42 = 3/14

So, the solution to the system of equations is:
x = 13/7
y = -3/14
z = 3/14
